plist.p: Well, good morning and welcome to the session of review of the H1 Business Results of Schneider Electric. I am here with Carina Ho and Emmanuel Babeau and we're going to comment together the first half of this year 2011.

Very quickly, going to slide five, a reminder of what is Schneider Electric today, a €21 billion sales company over the past 12 months – the last 12 months. And you find here the main characteristics of our company, a very global company, strong exposure to emerging countries, 38% of our turnover on the last 12 months, 39%, actually, on the last quarter. Strong investment in research and development, actually an investment that we have beefed up in the first half.

And a very diversified exposure in two directions, two geographies, a very balanced presence around the world, and around end markets with a very balanced presence on several end markets; on end markets which are infrastructure, industry, data centers, buildings and residential.

Going to slide six, remind you our commitment to sustainable development. Clean products, clean processes, commitment to ethical business. And the strong commitment to the development of the communities, where we work around our BipBop program for electrification of underprivileged people, on insertion of underprivileged youngsters, with a big commitment in education in our business, particularly the business of energy and electricity.

Moving onto the H1 results, more specifically, I would say that this first half was characterized by three things. The first point is a strong growth on both top line and the operating results. We confirmed a double-digit organic growth, current growth at 20%, mainly impacted by the adding of Areva Distribution, but also by the other acquisitions that we've done principally last year. And this strong growth on top line has been followed by a strong growth on the operating result with our EBITA growing by 14% in value.

The second characteristics of this first half, it has been a very strong deployment of our strategy. First element is an accelerated growth in new economies, which are representing, again, 39% of our turnover in Q2, and the total growth in H1 of 17% and we have clearly invested in the first half in a renewed way to make sure that we are present in the secondary cities and the more remote places of the new economies, the West of China, the East of Russia, the secondary cities of India, secondary cities of Brazil. Clearly we'd say that we would invest in 2011 and this has been a significant part of our investment.

Second transition we had in H1 is a strong surge of solutions in our turnover. Solutions represented 35% of our turnover, a growth of 14%. And this is a place where we have invested in H1. Solutions boosted our growth. The counterpart of it is that that they don't carry the same margin, so they put pressure – come back, they put pressure on – only if you can come back. Thank you. They put pressure on P&L margin on the first half. Last year was more of a product half, and this year was more of a solutions half.

Third point that really was a strong implementation of our strategy. It was an intense first half in terms of acquisitions. Many things come at maturity at the same time, with clearly where we executed acquisitions along the profile that we prefer to pursue, which are mid-sized acquisitions, service both new economies and solutions, but I will come back to that.

Third point that characterizes this first-half is clearly an unusual level of disturbances, which affects – that had impact in H1, but that we shall correct in H2. The first one has been a very strong impact of raw material cost inflation, the highest and the fastest we have ever known, actually €200 million plus in H1 and there's going to be more in H2. And actually, we need to be more proactive in pricing both solutions and products. But it took us, it takes some time to react to raw material inflation. Therefore, we see something were driving activity and that will kick in at a higher level in H2.

The second unusual disturbance was serious Japanese crisis and I have been very clear with that. We had taken the very strong orientation to save our customers and to make sure that we would be able to serve our customers. And therefore, we have taken a number of actions which have impacted our industrial costs, re-engineering of products, making sure we would map completely our supply chain and clearly, it has led us at the end of H1 to driving the inventory up far above the average of what we use to do. And this is something that we are going to be reducing in H2, because the news that we have from our supply chain are rather positive.

I mean, actually, we probably overestimated six months ago the impact of what was happening in Japan, but it was very difficult in two months ago to understand exactly what would be the impact. Today, we serve our customers, we served our customers. There has been no disruption with our customers, but clearly we have – it has provoked a surge in our inventory and therefore, an unusual deterioration of our cash generation.

So, the unusual fact on H1, it has been the density of acquisition. We have kept you informed of each of them. Most of them are small to medium, but it has incurred some cost, it has incurred some – a lot of activity and clearly. As I am going to tell you, the priority of the H2 is integration and will make sure that those acquisitions are coming solidly inside China.

So, I am going to go into the three engines of growth of this H1. They are also the main directions of our strategies. They are the core elements of our One program and I am going to start by solutions.

I already said most of it, but again, solutions make up 35% of our business in H1 with services representing 10% and the growth has been 14%, plus 4% respectively to the average of the group. As much as 2010 has been an unusually high level of activity in products, they were the early cycle in the rebound post crisis. The solutions, not surprisingly and we're been very clear on that all over, have taken more time to rebound and the first half has been dense in solutions. But again, positive drives growth, negative dilutes the margin. But anyway, you don't have the same capital employed, I repeat it, on solution.

What have we done? We are keeping on investing in software technologies, one of the big steps we are in the process of doing is, by the way, Telvent joining Schneider. We are developing architectures by market segments. We are putting into place commercial and execution centers and we are ramping up the services. I've always been very vocal that between the time you recruit somebody for solution and services and the time they produce revenue, you've got 18 months. So, it's an investment that we do gradually, but which is weighing clearly on our margins in solutions.

Slide – next slide, the second element of our strategy is the development of new economies. And when we look at the big picture, we doubled our size in new economies in the past five years. Most of it has been done organically. You would gather it. Actually, we are today doing €8 billion on the last 12 months in new economies. For me, it's a kind of market, because when I took over the operating management or the operations of the Group, the whole of Schneider was around this figure. I mean, we are doing around €8 billion in the whole of world and 80% was in the Western economies.

So, we've grown in the past seven years a pretty sizable company in the new economies, and what I like and what we're doing in new economies is the balanced aspect of it. We are presenting every new economies with very strong positions not only in Asia, which is the very center of what we do in new economies, but also in Middle East and Africa. In Latin America, we are really – we've redressed and grown very significant position particularly in Brazil, and clearly in Russia, where with the acquisition or the joint venture we have with Samara, we've doubled our position very recently. Here, the main axis are the geographical coverage, like many Western companies, we used to be strong in the main cities, in the main urban environments. We are really developing in a more capital way in those countries.

Commercial presence, which is really present everywhere in those places, very strong presence now in R&D and other development. I'll come back to that, because we start to be very visible. And we start now to develop our solutions and services as new economies as they develop. Now we're finding that it's smart to outsource things to people like us.

So, very strong element of Schneider, it's clearly a point of investment, both organically and externally by acquisitions in the first half. But it's a story which is developing in a very, very strong manner and which is becoming very central. The growth in Asia, particularly Asia Pac, has been spectacular in the past two or three years. We have reached a new size and one of the objectives that we have in the next years to come is to make sure that we consolidate and support this growth, based on the very solid footprint that we have in new economies.

Two other things I like in the new economies, well, I am not speaking about very large projects that are export projects. These are rooted activities in the economies of the new economies. And the last thing I like is that those business are as probably as profitable as what we do in major countries. We are not subsidizing new economies from the mature economies. Those new economies are developing in a mature and autonomous way.

Going to slide 11, you see very clearly that on Q2 – on Q1, the new economies have again generated a different sort of growth with respect to the mature countries of 10%. By the way, nothing to be very ashamed of in mature economies, very strong rebound based on the new activities that we developed.

The things that we develop in new economies are really based on the investment we do, on the new activities we are capturing. It's about services, it's about solutions, it's about energy efficiency, in some cases, it's about renewables. It's really things that we develop on markets which overall, when you take the average of Europe and the U.S., have still not recovered from the crisis. But you see really the strong kicker that new economies represent in our growth.

So, solutions, new economies, on new economies, just to give you a glimpse of things which are coming on the market, which are offers for new economies developed in new economies. You have got example here in energy. Actually, this is an offer coming from Areva. IT products, which are just developed for the new economies, which are carrying their own characteristics. Industry, we are very successful with products of this series of motion, which is totally adapted to the China market in this specific example, and others which are developed India for India, China for China, Brazil for Brazil and that we are developing, manufacturing locally at different functions on different value price points.

I am going to the third engine of our growth, which is acquisition. You know it's been always proper for our model at Schneider. We are a €21 billion company in an accessible market, which is above €200 billion, so it's still very fragmented. And there were many things that came to maturity in the first half, and that has taken a lot of our activity, we acknowledge it. But when you look at the past 18 months, fundamentally, we've done a certain number of acquisition. We have acquired for roughly €3 billion of turnover. Half of it is about solutions, half of it is about new economies. And actually when you look at it, there is an overlap of €1 billion of solutions in new economy, so it's €2 billion in new economies, €2 billion in solutions, of which €1 billion is overlapping.

Now you would say, well, it's a lot. Actually there are large two acquisitions, Areva D and Telvent, which are kind of the exceptions to the typical profile of our acquisitions, but when then you look at rest, it's typically what we are used to do, I mean small, medium acquisition, very often in a private negotiation, very often with private owners and bolt-on companies which are integrating pretty easily, with a lot of work, but which are integrating quite naturally in our company.

Again, we've got very strict criterias, financial criterias in our acquisitions. They are not the only one, the first one is obviously is the strategic fit, the second one is the cultural fit. But the financial criterias are very strict and every time we don't go with a typical criteria, which is roughly above the €1 billion, we announce it and we tell it very transparently in our communication. So, you are informed of every time where we decide to make an exception, which is not often, by the way.
Our debt structure is very, very – our balance sheet is very solid, but Emmanuel will come back on that.

So, what strikes me in H1 is that it has been an intense application for implementation of our strategy. What we see today is that energy efficiency is mainstream. And by the way, what – the tragedy that happened in Japan, and especially the pressure it puts on nuclear industry, is making the two technology banners, Germany and Japan, have decided to adopt new energy models and to be stronger on energy efficiency.

We totally support this. We believe that we need all kinds of generation, but anyway, that the world will become – will have to become more efficient. And clearly, we have an edge today on the solutions and particularly the, what we call eco-structure, in the field of energy efficiency solutions. So, what you saw in the first half is a development technologically around the eco-structure breaks and in terms of competence with a set-up of competency centers on our solutions for energy efficiency particularly are developing by 14%, growing by 14%.

Smart grid emerging on the most striking element of the first half, and this time, it's the offer on Telvent, which is bringing – which is doubling our software capabilities in the field of the smart grid. Our new economies are driving the world growth, the striking difference between the debt in the mature countries and the capacities of financing in the new economies, where we are well rooted, not because we decided yesterday to go there, but we decided a long time ago, and it's a well-rooted, well – I'm very happy at present that we have there, again, 17% in H1.

I'd like to go to the next slide, slide 15. I'll remind you that we worked on our productivity, on efficiency in the first half. And clearly, we delivered a good productivity, a bit below last year. There was certainly less volume rupture or change in this first half. And also, we have impacted, we could have done better in purchasing and absorption of fixed manufacturing cost, but we had to make some important compromises with electronics, due to what happened in Japan and the ruptures in the supply chain.

And there was a lot of work also in reengineering – there is a series of products that we totally reengineered, because some of the components were not there anymore. I mean, the factories have been wiped out. And we reengineered, which is, in my dialect, a tour de force, they were reengineered in like two months and made available with the customers.

Obviously, we decided to overstock to cover the crisis. And this is very visible in our cash, which is, for the first time, negative, but this is mainly due to the inventory. And we kept working on our support function cost with respect to our sales, reaching 24.5% of our sales in H1 2011. This been helped this time by Areva D, because this is a place where Areva D is helping a lot for the margin, the integration of Areva D has decreased the average margin of the group, but this is very mechanical and very explainable.
Now, I am going to hand over to Emmanuel for the presentation.
Thank you. Let's move into some details on numbers and first of all, let's look at the details of the performance of our sales by business.

In total, our sales amounted to €10,336 million during the first half. It's a 21% growth versus H1 2010. Before looking at the organic performance, let's look at scope and ForEx. ForEx is slightly negative, it's 1% negative. That is marginal, but we expect this ForEx impact to be more negative toward the end of the year, as we see a continued depreciation of the dollar versus the euro. Therefore, we can expect a negative impact which will be stronger at the end of the year at the ForEx level.

Change in scope, it's mainly what Areva is bringing in terms of sales, but it also includes impact of acquisitions such as Uniflair or Lee Technologies. And I am now moving to organic growth, 10.2% during this first half. It was almost 12% during the first quarter. It's almost 9% during the second quarter. So, we kept a very good momentum on our growth.

By business now, as you can see, industry is clearly leading the chart here with 18% organic growth. Industry business is growing in each region. So, the dynamism is not limited here to new economy. We really see a nice and strong growth everywhere. The competition for industry player is there. There is a need for more productivity. There is a need for energy efficiency and it is clearly developing very nicely as a business.

If we look at our product, clearly, there is a very strong demand for motion and drive-related product. And if we look at solutions, we have been developing very well our OEM, the machine builder solution business, during this first half.

Moving now to the other businesses. Power, 9% growth. Power is developing extremely well in new economies. No need to say that there is a nice construction market, well-oriented in new economy, but there is also strong investment in low voltage for infrastructure, for industry that is driving the growth.

When we look at the metro country, in the U.S., we have seen a rebound, but which is clearly not driven by what we see in the construction, because here, there is no rebound in the U.S. neither in residential nor in non-residential. So, it is what we sell in term of low voltage through the industry and through the data center and market which is the engine of the growth.

In Europe, there is some positive situations, such as France or Germany, where we see, notably in France, some positive sign in the construction market, although still limited. But we have a big drag with the Spanish situation, which is extremely difficult and significantly negative.

Moving to the energy performance, 5% organic growth. Energy has been accelerating between Q1 and Q2. Q1 was only marginally positive. So, indeed, we know that this business is more late cycle than many of our other activity. And we are seeing momentum rising notably in new economy, with the project and infrastructure in oil and gas and that is generating a nice increase of the business, 9% organic growth on the second quarter.

IT business, almost 10% growth through this first half. We are seeing a very nice development of demand for the big system, big data center project, largely related to the development of the cloud. At the same time and notably in the mature country, because situation is still good in the new economy, we see a slowdown in the growth for small systems. So, that is somewhat slowing down the IT performance, which has been still very solid with this 10% growth.

Buildings, well, I remind you that today, buildings is, I think, the lowest exposure to new economy. So, of course, that is somewhat a disadvantage for this business. Still, a 7% growth during this period. We've seen very strong demand for services and notably, advanced services, so strong added value to our client in the building industry to manage their energy.

We see a nice development for solution and project around security and we have seen a nice growth in new economy, which is start to develop well and certainly, we are investing a lot there to achieve that. We are seeing projects around energy efficiency in new economy gathering momentum.

Moving to the performance by region, in fact, apart from Western Europe, we've been reaching double-digit growth in all the other three region. But let's start with the new economy, that is the most striking performance and Asia Pac, of course, as the first one, 17%. We are experiencing a 20% growth plus rate in China, in India and in Southeast Asia during this first half. So, a very strong performance globally on this region. And we are not reaching globally for Asia Pac, this 20%, because the Pacific region has grown at more moderate pace, but otherwise, it's a very powerful performance from Asia Pac during this first half.

Rest of the world and I stay therefore on new economy, that is one region which actually accelerated between the first quarter and the second quarter. We see very good situation in Latin America and not only even Brazil, Brazil is, of course, very good, but we see Colombia, Chile, Peru doing extremely well. We've seen very strong performance in Russia as well and Middle East has been developing well. Africa, which was negative and very negative during the first quarter, stabilized during the second quarter.

Now moving to the mature country, North America is 11%. If I look at the U.S., we have continued to deliver strong performance in industry. We have continued to see this rebound I was mentioning on power. On IT, I did mention the situation of a mixed bag between big system and small system. Mexico and Canada were also extremely good.

Now finishing with Western Europe, very contrasted situation. You have some markets, which has really been developing well, such as Germany, Italy and France. You have markets which are around stability, such as the U.K. and you have the Spanish market, which is significantly negative.

Now moving to the detail of the P&L, as you can see, this is another six months where we have been able to significantly improve our EBITA margin and of course, I am looking at comparable data here on the right hand part of the chart. As you can see, we reached an EBITA before acquisition and integration cost of €1,413 million. This is 13% growth compared to last year and we have increased our EBITA margin by 40 basis points. We are therefore one more time able to grow our operating profit quicker than our sales. And here, even though at the level of the gross margin, we have been impacted by a very negative headwind linked to the raw material inflation.

But precisely, this is what I would like to detail now and the various impacts that we have experienced and that led to this performance and improvement in profitability. Of course, the big negative element of this first six months, let's be clear, is absolutely a record negative impact of raw material for the group. I've been looking to the past number and I think the worst performance – the worst number that we experienced in the past was a negative element for the full year in 2007 of €260 million. That was for the 2007 year.

Just in six months, we've experienced a negative raw material impact of €213 million, so something that we have never seen in the past. If you add some other inflation impact, it's 250 million negative. In front of that, I mean we continued to be extremely efficient in delivering productivity and in fact, we almost matched with the productivity this negative element linked to inflation.

We also put some price increase, 0.5% overall, certainly below what we should have been doing during this first half. Let's be clear. We have been somewhat caught by surprise by the speed and the volatility on the inflation on raw material. It takes some time to put the price increase, to inform the clients to put that through various channel and we are actually being very ambitious for the second half, we'll do much better than that. But we have this 0.5% performance on the first half and we really, in fact, mainly measure, as Jean- Pascal said, the performance on the product business more than on the solution business.

Then we have a mix impact, which has been negative, not surprisingly. As we are growing into the solution business, we know that we are having a negative impact at the level of the margin, but we don't see that as an issue, let's be clear. This growth in solution is increasing our top line dynamism. This is extra EBIT generated and this is extra cash generated for the company, so the fact that it is having a negative impact on the EBIT margin mechanically is not a negative element. It's just something mechanical that we have to take into account.

Now in front of this evolution of the gross margin, we have been able to grow our support function costs at a lower pace than our sales, 7% organic growth for our support function costs, more than 10% for our top line, a differential of three points between top line and our cost, and that shows two things. The first one, of course, is that we've been impacted by inflation. That's around €90 million impact, but that also we took the decision, again very consistently, to keep investing for the future growth of Schneider Electric, and that explains why we have this growth of 7%.

This is extremely well planned, we know where we are investing in businesses such as IT, in businesses such as building. We know the geographies where we want to invest to be stronger tomorrow, and again, I mean, we are certainly in an adverse environment in some dimension, we are showing that this is something we can do and continue to do efficiently in the future.

Now looking at the profitability by business, you see that globally, you have three categories of performance. First one and star, Industry, which is increasing very nicely, its profitability 2.3 points. Here, of course you have the growth impact which is playing positively. The fact that probably industry has been less impacted than other by the raw material inflation and that is, of course, playing. And the fact that this is not a business where the solution are the most important and where they are representing the IS share.

Second category, businesses where we have stable margin as a case of power and energy and here, we have been able to compensate the inflation for raw material. And then two negative evolution of profitability, IT and Building. This is, of course, the weight of solutions for these two businesses. This is the raw material inflation and this is, again, the very conscious decision that we need to invest for the future in these two businesses and that is, of course, having an impact on the profitability at new economies here.

Now very quickly down to the end of the P&L, €41 million of integration cost. This is mainly not Areva cost, but costs that we have incurred through the various acquisition that we have announced. More specific comment on amortization of intangibles very much in line with last year, with the Areva part in addition.

Net financial expenses, it's growing compared to last year, but the reality is that cost of our debt, what we have been paying in term of financial interest, is €10 million lower than last year, so we keep reducing the cost of our debt. The reason for this increase is a pure ForEx impact. Last year, we had a €40 million positive impact in the first half, this year, we have a €20 million negative impact, so it's a €60 million difference, which explains the deterioration of the financial expenses line. Income tax, very much stable, we are at 24% and we believe that we should finish the year around the 24% income tax rate for the group.
Taking into account equity investment, minority interest, that lead us to our net income group share, which reached €802 million. It's almost a 10% growth compared to last year.

Now moving to the free cash flow and that clearly deserve a significant explanation, because that is something extremely specific that happened during this first half. First of all, a general comment. We build most of our cash flow during the second half of the year. I mean, we have the seasonality on the cash flow generation and if we look in the past, we have been consistently generating between 60% and 80% of our cash flow during the second part of the year. And that will continue to be the case.

Now on top of that, there is some non-recurring element that has been impacting this first half and that we do intend to correct during the second half of the year. The big drift, in fact, is coming from the working capital, which in total is almost growing by €1 billion.

If I look first on our trade working capital, it's a €770 million growth of our need in working capital, with the first reason behind that, of course, is the growth of the activity, 10% growth, very sustained top line and that is having some impact mechanically on the level of our working capital. But on top of it, as Jean-Pascal explained, we consciously took the decision in order to ensure the delivery of our client to increase the level of inventory and we saw that it was something that we could support on the provisional basis in order to make sure that we would not be losing sales.

And as a matter of fact, I think that first of all, we have not been impacted. But we have seen some clients coming to us and saying that they were facing difficulty with some other supplier. Which means that certainly you know, that's a decision that have been helping us, and in terms of relation with the client, that has been perceived very positively. Probably also some elements that much more marginal on the receivable that will be collected at the end of the year. And that explains the total evolution of the trade working capital.

Now in addition, we have a €200 million negative impact on the non-trade working capital and here it's, of course, the sum of various elements, very significant bonuses and premiums that have been accrued for at the end of 2010 on the back of a very good year for the employees that we paid during this first half. Some tax element as well that has been playing. Some cost and charges that had been booked and provisioned and that we paid in terms of guarantee and so on during this quarter. So, that explains this amount. We do expect, again, the total impact to be much lower toward the end of the year.

Last, but it's also a meaningful element, which is that we are increasing our capital expenditure amount. We are growing from €218 million last year to €329 million. We are back to something more normal in terms of CapEx, around 3% of sales. And this is, I think, a €100 million negative impact. So, that is really all these elements together that accounts for this negative free cash flow during the first half. Something again that has to be seen as a one-off and something that will be corrected during the second part of the year.

Facing the dividend that we have paid, the acquisition, sorry, not finished yet. Thank you. Taking the dividend, acquisition, capital increase and other elements, we have a debt which is slightly below €4.5 billion at the end of June 2011.

Now this is just to highlight what I have explained, in fact that really, the building up of our working capital during the first half. You have this evolution of inventory and the decision that we have made and this objective, obviously, we have €300 million of excess inventory that will be corrected during the second half of the year. And that is clearly something that we are taking as a top priority during the second half for all the teams.

We retain a very strong balance sheet. As you can see, our net debt to EBITDA is at a low 1.2 times, so in line with what we had at the end of 2009. The EBITDA reach almost €1.7 billion. And we have more than €2 billion of cash that's included in the balance sheet, so we retain a very healthy balance sheet situation.
Jean-Pascal, are you ready for the outlook?

Yeah, sure. So, while the first thing is to look at our priorities today on – I'm going to share an internal document which is where we drive our teams today, we continue to drive organic growth. We've got some very interesting spots of the business with high dynamics. We spoke about the new economies. We spoke about our new activities in major countries. So, we keep capturing new opportunities in energy efficiency, in the smart grid and in the new economies.

Second point obviously is to ramp up the price actions. And this is about products, which makes 65% of our business. And to as Emmanuel said it, this is principally where we measure the price increases, but it's the control of the margin on the solutions, which are developing faster now. And where we need to make sure and we are working so that we make sure we integrate also the ramp-up of our MI, of raw material inflation, inside the pricing on the delivery of solution.

Operational efficiency, industrial productivity. SFC on sales, we see something where we've put strong control in H2 as we are now reaching basis of comparison which are bit higher. The fourth point on efficiency would be the reduction of inventories, which we've done last year also to make sure that we drive cash conversion. Now that – since now two months, we now understand that the Japanese crisis is not behind us, but that we have mastered the consequences of it on the delivery to our customers.
And finally, obviously, a lot of focus on the integration of the acquisitions, big or small or medium size and make sure that we deliver synergies.

So, if you go to slide 28, well, on the top line, most of the Group's end markets expected to continue to develop positively. The markets which are the least favorable are the residential and non-residential markets in the mature markets where we don't expect any much rebound or expect much dynamics. On the other hand, we expect a robust momentum in the new economies, which will continue, but on the basis of higher comps of last year. And we have to integrate globally the higher basis of comparison in H2.

In terms of profitability, H2 profitability is better than H1 in the typical Schneider profile. We have to go back a long way to find a normal year at Schneider between 2008, 2009, 2010. All those profiles were totally distorted. And but if you come back to the good old years, where the world was, between brackets, normal, we had a far better profit generation and cash generation in H2 and we are kind of back into a more normal year.

The negative solution product mix on gross margin, but helping on the top line. We are going to accelerate the price actions and we tied the increase, as we said, of 1% of sales to partly offset the raw material headwind that now we estimate at €400 million with the new dynamics of raw material.

Industrial productivity in excess of €400 million on the basis of good volumes, on the basis of more serenity on the electronics side. And finally, we are going to keep reducing the support function costs to the sales ratio. So, if we have the macro conditions that we have today, we confirm our organic growth target of 6% to 9% and clearly, we would feel comfortable with that guidance with the first half that we have scored.

Now on the EBITA, we target an EBITA margin this time more around 15%, which is more closer to the bottom of the bracket that we had announced at the beginning of the year and seeing the intensity of what we do in acquisition and the cost incurred, on the inconsistency with what we did last year and it's before acquisition integration cost and related integration of cost of 2011 acquisitions. So, that's about the outlook, good on the top line and on – at 15% on the operating margin for the year.
And now, we are ready to take your questions.
So, we'll now open the Q&A section. And we'll start with questions from the room and after that, we'll take questions, some questions by phone. Olivier?

Hello. Olivier Esnou, Exane. Maybe two questions. On the growth, if I look at your peer group, they have given a slightly now organic growth. I mean, maybe if you could give us some feeling, having H1 now in the back and some backlog, still even if it's not a future of Schneider, where you feel – if you feel a bit more comfortable knowing a little bit that?

And then on the pricing, the second question. The pricing versus raw mat dynamic, do you think for the year, where you will be in terms of coverage? Well, on the bracket of growth, clearly at the end of H1, we feel, we are well-positioned in this bracket. There are some debate about the debt in Europe, in the U.S. Although we don't take hypothesis of major ruptures, it's clearly creating some uncertainly. So, we prefer to stay cautious, all right?

But with 10% in H1 and we have steady backlog actually, probably the highest in terms of amount that we've known. We are entering into H2 with a good momentum. So, that's for the top line. Now we have also to humbly say is that we measure the price increases mostly on the product part of the business, the transactions, while on the 35% of our business which is solution, it's about margin control. Okay. Just one follow-up maybe, €200 million coverage out of €400 million, how should we read that? Yeah, you have a carryover.

Yeah.

It's been – as Emmanuel was saying, probably it's the double and twice faster than what we knew before. So, we didn't see everything. We didn't appreciate it to this magnitude.
Gaël?

Hal has made the good work of maintaining the supply chain during the Japanese crisis and it was sometimes complicated and Annette now is strongly focused on making sure that our inventories is coming down to the level where it should be in regard to the operations.

Alfred?

Well on China, we are not specific on every zone, but it's above the average of Asia Pac, so very strong and very dynamic today. And for the rest, for the perspective, I was clear enough, I think, in my previous answer. Middle East is doing well with very high contrast between region Dubai, which is still an Emirate, which is still down, Emirates, and other places which are doing far better, Saudi Arabia being one example. What we do in Turkey is also very good. So, but globally, Middle East is doing well.

Looking at Africa, as Emmanuel said it, this is the only negative place and this is due to what we have in North Africa, which is – we had a strong position and we have a strong position in Egypt, which is going through low activity at the moment and traditionally, we see also some strong position in North Africa.

On South Africa, which at the moment is weak for reasons which are linked to the global macro environment there. Today, we've resized on like in these cases, like it happens in the new economies, we are waiting for the new environment.

Regarding the margin of Areva D, no, in fact, we are no longer able to split that because really, the business is merged, so we are not able to say what was previously Areva and what is now Schneider. Regarding the cost reduction and productivity under one program, well, let's be clear, we have the ambition on the long-term and on a very regular basis to generate significant productivity. Good morning, . I am from Natixis, but on the investment banking side, not on the research side. And what has been relevant at the given moment will lose relevance in the future, be less connected with the evolution, the direction that we are giving to the Group. Okay. So, we'll start...

You have a question from Andreas Willi from JPMorgan. Please go ahead.

Good morning. Thanks for taking my question. My first question is on inventory. You had a very good drop through rate on your volume growth in the first half of this year, was this also partly due because you overproduced relative to what you sold, so maybe you could give us the year-on-year increase in production volume relative to the year-on-year increase in your sales volume?

For our IT business, clearly, there has been a change of mix and this is really a story of cycle first. We know that in this business, the early cycle are the small products, the network and the business network products, which are the one-phase products. And data centers come with a different business model. As you know, you get a project with a low margin and then you make a profit through the services that are from data centers and we are in this phase where we do proportionally less transactional on one-phase products. Taking the projects and generating in the future more services. We have not seen ruptures on the competitive conditions today on the market. We've launched our new products in smart ups in smaller products, where as always, at the ramp up of the products, you've got the ramp, you've got the productivity to install or the right cost to install, but it's been marginal on all things. Last thing that we – I have to say that North America, for one phase products, the market has been not as good as last year. Clearly, it has been – it's linked to servers and the market of servers has not been as favorable for the one-phase product.

I don't think I can be more precise than that at that stage. And on acquisition cost, as we don't know yet, we have still a number of projects which are expecting approval. There is a number of costs still going on. I'm not able today to clarify what could be the impact for the full year. We'll do that as soon as we have a clear view on them.

Good morning. I have a few questions, please. In terms of pricing, I just want to get back to that. Did you take any price increases in H1 at all? Because there was a bit of a price increase on the bridge, but it seemed quite small, and did you have any problems taking prices?

You get the cost before you get the prices through and we are glad you could – we should have been more proactive probably on that thing, on the path. And we say that familiar to pricing, principally on the product side, which is 65% of the business. But I don't want to come back into all the details.

And the commodities that impacted us, there is a part of plastic but it's certainly not the dominating part. What was the most dominating in H1 was copper and was silver. We had the transportation cost, because we are global company, we transfer products and that goes with oil and oil is not a cheap thing anymore, which by the way, is very good for our energy efficiency activity.

Yeah, which is very much what I answered to Andreas and there is a clear differentiation, restructuring costs. When we talk about the restructuring cost of €100 million that we had last year, it's what we do within the group to permanently optimize the structure of the group to manage a difficult situation here or there. Again, we are not giving guidance which is before the restructuring costs this year. So, when we are giving this around 15% EBITA margin objective, that is after discussed of restructuring. I am clear on that. And then, we are not changing the guidance, but when you start the year, frankly speaking, you have no idea of what the M&A business is going to be, what the M&A activity is going to be, which kind of cost you are going to incur. And it can be very small at the end of the year or very big if something has emerged as an important acquisition.

So, by nature, I would say we are simply not able to forecast that as it cannot be included in the guidance. So, that's just what we are clarifying here and I hope that those things are absolutely are crystal clear.

On pricing, back to pricing, it's really to cut a long story short, it's really more a story of timing so far. And you say that on – yeah, but it's really a question of timing. I mean, it takes time to get the pricing through and again, we should have been probably more faster to implement our price increases.
